title: How to Open a Paint Can

methods.name: Using a Tool to Open the Can

steps.headline: Select a paint can opener for the easiest option.
steps.description: Paint can openers are small tools designed to effortlessly pry the lid off of your can. When you buy your paint from a home supply store, ask the associate for a paint can opener as well. Oftentimes they give these out for free along with the purchase of your paint. Paint can openers are also available for purchase at most home supply stores. Paint can openers have a small, curved tip that easily gets underneath the lip of the paint can so you can lift it up.

steps.headline: Use a flathead screwdriver if you don’t have a paint can opener.
steps.description: While a paint can opener is the best way to open a paint can, you can also use a screwdriver. Be careful not to put too much pressure on the lid when using a screwdriver, or it can get deformed. For best results, use a screwdriver with a tip about ⁄4–⁄2 in (0.64–1.27 cm) big. If you use a smaller screwdriver, opening the can may put too much pressure on the rim of the can and it can get deformed. If your lid is deformed, it will be harder to close and take off next time.

steps.headline: Try a stiff, 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) putty knife if you have one handy.
steps.description: In addition to paint can removers and screwdrivers, putty knives work well to open paint cans. If you choose a putty knife, use the side of the knife to maximize your surface area. These work well because you can easily pry the lid off with the thick, wide blade of the putty knife.

steps.headline: Hold your tool under the lip of the lid to easily pry it off.
steps.description: Place the tip of your tool underneath the lip. If using a screwdriver or putty knife, it is helpful to use the side of the tool to gain more leverage.

steps.headline: Press down on the handle of the tool to pry open the lid.
steps.description: After you position your tool under the lid, use moderate force on the handle. With a little bit of effort, the lid will separate from the paint can. If the lid does not come off the can in 1 motion, reposition your tool and try again.

steps.headline: Open the paint can a little bit at a time to maintain the shape of the lid.
steps.description: Continue prying the lid off in a consecutive motion. To do this, scoot the tool across the lid and lift up every ⁄2–1 in (1.3–2.5 cm) or so. Prying all of the lid off before opening the can prevents the lid from getting deformed and bent. If the lid loses its flat shape, it will be hard to put the lid back on. If you take the lid off from 1 side, you will bend it.

steps.headline: Take the lid off with your hands.
steps.description: Once you pry the lid off all the way around, place 1 hand on the lid, and gently lift up. Put the lid down on a flat surface with the paint side facing upwards. This way, you can easily pick up the lid when you are finished painting.

steps.headline: Wipe the rim of the can with a paint brush to remove any excess paint.
steps.description: When you are finished painting, hold the tip of your brush up to the rim of your can, and move it around in a circle. Then, wipe the tip of your brush against the lid. This moves the paint on the rim back into the can. This way, your lid will not get sticky with paint. Alternatively, you can use a rag instead of a paintbrush.

steps.headline: Place the lid on top on the rim when you are finished painting.
steps.description: After you wipe around the rim, lift up your lid and put it on top of the paint can with the paint side facing down.

steps.headline: Tap the lid into place using a hammer or rubber mallet.
steps.description: Once the lid is in place, make small tapping motions on the lid. Continue tapping around the lid clockwise until the lid is securely in place. For best results, use a tool with a small head. You don’t need to pound the lid into place, and you can more easily tap the lid closed using a small tool.
